bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 16, 1900

div1.p: Reed writes that he cannot return home. He describes the enthusiastic response to the experiments, and he prepares a paper for the Pan-American Medical Congress.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 16, 1900
div1.opener:
Two Kisses
for Doogy
T. Johnson,
Love to Lucy.
Camp Columbia,
Quemados, Cuba,
Dec. 16th 1900.
My precious wifie:
div1.p:
Will you
excuse the use of a lead
pencil? Somebody seems to have
borrowed my ink, and so I
am compelled to resort to
a pencil- Here I am sitting
in my shirt sleeves with
the thermometer at 75° at
9 P.M.- I couldn't possibly
find time to write yesterday
in answer to your letter
of Dec. 10th- The day was so
busily occupied with the
affairs of our experimen-
tal station that I was kept
on the jump all day long.
I had to smile at the advice
that my darling wife was
giving me about not trying
to experiment now, but to
postpone until next
summer, “when the mosquitoes
have more vigor”- When
I read that, our fourth
man's eyes were getting
redder and his temperature
higher, and as far as I was
was able to judge, the insect
appeared to be “getting in
his work” very well!
What do you think of that
for winter experimentation?
Four out of five inoculated
coming down promptly?
Oh! my! but the last week
has been an eventful one
for your old Mr Mantee!
And what is perfectly de-
lightful, the first three
may be considered out
of danger, while the fourth,
only sick 24 hours, is
doing as well as could
be expected at this stage
of the disease- This morn-
ing, we again had the ex-
perts out from Havana,
and it was very amus-
ing to see our three
Spaniards all in a row,
as it were, occupying
their three beds, and look-
ing (at least two of them)
quite contented over the
near prospect of $200.00
in good american gold!
our experiments have op-
ened the eyes of all ar-
ound- I sent a Cable to
Gen. Sternberg, yesterday,
and another, to-day,- I should
not be surprised, if he
really fell out of his chair!
I wonder if the good news
has made my precious
wifie any better! I am
so anxious to hear- My!
but the first part of that
last letter was as blue
as indigo!- like my joy's
Sunday that she spoke
of! How could I talk or
arrange about coming
home, my precious joy,
When I had my hands
so very full of most im-
portant work? Indeed,
I don't want to come
here next summer, if I
can possibly get out of
it- I had much rather
finish now and have done
with it- As matters stand
now, I don't see how I
can possibly finish my
present work till the
last of next month --
and then comes the Pan-
American Medical Cong-
ress which meets Feb,
5th -- was postponed
from Christmas week --
and we should certainly
present a Short Report
to the Congress, as it would
be of the highest impor-
tance to do so- Several
hundred physicians from
South America Mexico
and many prominent men from the U.S
would will be here, and I am
sure that we should not
lose the opportunity of
bringing to their prompt
attention these most im-
portant observations
on yellow fever- The paper
will attract more attention
that any other that will
be presented- I say this
in all modesty- It's even
more important to have
ascertained how this
disease is propagated than
to find the parasite that
causes it -- our observations
completely revolutionize
the opinions heretofore
held on the subject -- and must
be of the greatest benefit
to the U.S. and to this Island.
Americans will no longer
dread to come here, now
that they will know how
to avoid the infection.
Now, I am hoping to hear
what my darling wifie
is going to say about her
future movements -- whether
you have made up your
mind to come or not- If
I had a good mess for
you, I would urge you
to come down, but as
things are, I cannot do so-
That must be left for your
own determination- Other-
wise, you could be made
perfectly comfortable and
happy- As it is, it makes
me very unhappy to know
that my sweet wifie is
so wretched mentally and
physically- If I could leave
tomorrow, I would gladly
do so, but common sense
and my judgment tell me not
to do so. monday morning. 17th.
Boo! Boo! sweetheart, Dr Ames
has just reported that our
fourth case is doing splendidly-
temperature has fallen to 99°3/5-
Isn't that just glorious? Four
cases and no deaths, but
my sweet wifie said that they would
all die and that the country would
turn against me and that I
would be everlastingly
disgraced! He! He! Miss
Gouty, you will change
your mind when you are
“Mrs. Surgeon General” and
holding big receptions on
K St.! “Go long,” you pre-
cious Farmer- lady and stop
trying to make your old Mr
Mantee come home! You
know that you don't want
to see him one little bit!
You just want somebody
to rub that fat toe!
By the time he does get back,
you will have recovered
from the attack of gout
and be “fatter & prettier” than
ever, as Dr Nash would
say- I am going in to see
Gen. Wood, this morning,
with Major Kean, in order
to tell him concerning
our success- Somehow
or other, I feel very happy,
this morning, and wish that
I had my two pretty girls
here just to give them
a Kiss & a hug! Don't for-
get to get for each other those
pretty Christmas presents.
Don't worry over presents
for others- Goodbye, you pret-
ty pictures- Kisses & love & love
& Kisses for my precious babies!!
